definition: forcible or passive resistance to lawful authority, concerted (see concerted sense 1) revolt (as of a naval crew) against discipline or a superior officer
examples: The sailors staged a mutiny and took control of the ship.

definition: to rise against or refuse to obey or observe authority, to rebel against military authority : to stage a mutiny
examples: He mutinied not just against God but against the older generation of Romanian intellectuals.
Months wore on, and about half of [Christopher] Columbus's men mutinied and tried to sail by canoe to Hispaniola.
In April 1779 a draft of sixty men from the 71st Highlanders mutinied when they were told they were to go to America and refused to march aboard the transports.
